awd_titl_txt: Ultrasonic Assisted Cold Sintering:  Kinetics of Densification and Grain Growth Study in Binary Oxide Ceramics
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: For over 25,000 years, human-kind has been using a manufacturing process known as sintering that uses both high temperatures and long processing times. It is believed that we are no longer confined to these high energy, inefficient traditional strategies. Through the use of the transient liquid phase, it has been found that ceramic materials can be sintered at unprecedented low temperatures. Through accelerated stimulus with ultrasound, it is hypothesized that even lower temperatures in greater efficiencies in the sintering process can be gained for a broad variety of inorganic materials, including the possible use in refractory materials, such as bricks. With such energy reductions in the process, it is anticipated that future techniques would be more efficient and lower cost.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The kinetics of sintering in terms of densification and grain growth are considered and quantified in simple binary materials under cold (at or under 300°C) sintering conditions. Detailed structural studies are being correlated with the various stages of sintering. Densification kinetics are being determined with a dilatometer in a modified mechanical tester. Transmission electron microscopy and impedance spectroscopy are being used to consider defect microstructure, stoichiometry, and defect chemistry monitoring differences in the cold sintering relative to process parameters. This base line data on model binary oxide systems provides critical insights into the nature of the cold sintering mechanisms. A complementary effort builds on those investigations and addresses the question on if and how ultrasonic radiation can be utilized to enhance the kinetics of cold sintering. There is literature pointing to ultrasonic radiation and sonochemistry that can improve particle compaction, dissolution, and precipitation, naturally leading to the conjecture that many mechanisms and stages of the cold sintering will be positively impacted.

por.por_cntn:
The research component successful considered some of the fundamental mechanisms that underpinned the newly introduced Cold Sintering Process. Sintering is a materials fabrication process that mankind has used for over 28,000 years from the late Paleolithic period. Ceramic figurines artefacts have been found and determined to have been fired from powders of clay mixed with water in earthen trench kilns. From ancient potters into the modern age of advanced ceramics the sintering process has used high temperature to drive the powders into a densified microstructure, eliminating porosity, and improving strength, and other properties. Advanced ceramics are important materials that enable components across all areas of modern society in computation, communication, transport, energy storage and management, manufacturing, healthcare, and military hardware.

              Typically, ceramics are sintering at 50% to 90% of the melting temperatures, ceramics having high melting points, and the sintering temperatures are around 1000 oC and higher. These high temperatures are required in conventional sintering to drive the diffusion processes of atomic species at the particle contact points. In contrast the Cold sintering process enables densification at temperatures less than 350 oC, and this is enabled with the chemo-mechanical process that involves intermediate applied pressures, low temperatures and all-important chemical transient phase that permits low temperature dissolution, transport, and precipitation. As illustrated in Figure 1 a) we see the process that is occurring under the cold sintering process, the first begins with the dissolution of the atomic constituents with the transient phase between the particle contacts. This creates a concentration gradient that permits diffusion of the species along the interface, there can then be a precipitation on the surface in the pore region between the particles. These processes work in harmony and as the process progresses the powder densifies, change shape and grains can grow consistent with the conventionally known sintering process. However, now sintering is happening at temperatures an order of magnitude below the conventional temperatures for each respective material. Figure 1 b) shows an example of the microstructure of cold sintered ceramic, Na-Al2O3  at 150 oC, and conventionally sinters at about 1700 oC, the activating chemical phase was acetic acid.

              ZnO was one of the model materials studied under this program, and using different temperature heating rates and isothermal temperature holds with different times and monitoring the densification and grain sizes revealed important details on the activation energies that controlled the sintering process. These activation energies for densification and grain growth gives insights into the why the temperatures can be so low, and what controls the process. The various sintering parameters have been considered with respect to temperature, chemistry, applied pressure and time to control the densification and microstructure under the cold sintering process. From those studies the fundamental mechanisms control the sintering could be understood with respect to the dissolution, transport, and precipitation. The basic science that this project developed has now led to several groups around the world following the concepts of cold sintering and explaining the field and understanding. This will all help to accelerate both the science and engineering of this new discovery in sintering.

              The broader impact of this work is multifaceted immediately we can appreciate the energy savings that can potentially be gained if the processing can be reduced to manufacturing scale. There is also new types of composite materials that can be fabricated with the cold sintering process. We have already demonstrated the ability to have nanomaterials integrated into the grain boundaries of a dense ceramics.  So cold sintering not only offers a sustainable process it also provides a common platform for integration of many different composite materials to modify grain boundary properties.

There were two major outreach activities that this project enabled one was in the form of a workshop that we organized at the African Materials Research Society in Tanzania, Arusha, (2019).  Professor Esther Obonyo organized a workshop on sustainable low-cost building materials for remote populations in the region. A broad group of speakers were brought together from funding government agencies in Africa, government policy representatives, building consultants, brick companies, and academics. We introduced cold sintering for low CO2  brick construction that would use local minerals such as laterite.  In 2022, student Lorine Ouma presented a paper at the African Materials Research Society, Senegal updating the progress and refined processes on cold sintering natural soils and mining waste, Figure 2.

To also increase the broader educational outreach of cold sintering we developed a You-Tube video entitled ?Cold Sintering Catalyzes a Sustainable Energy Future?. A graduate student (Sun Hwi Bang) that was instrumental in the fundamental research described above also co-directed and wrote the script for the video. This video was designed to teach people the basic process and provide insights to the process and its potential impact, Figure 3. The video can be found at https://youtu.be/u9PQQhH5TZs.
